ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about different types of energy and the ways that energy is organized and distributed.
This class covers different types of renewable energy systems and a bit of science and math behind the processes.
Learned about how our world renewable resources work

I learned a wide variety of technologies, physics, current events, and trends around both global and US renewable energy. It was a great balance of technical skills and important insights in the world of renewable energy. We covered pretty much every technology - hydropower, wind power, solar power, geothermal, nuclear, ocean power, and went into even more detail within some of the categories.
Covers topics in renewable energy (solar, geothermal, hydro, ocean, nuclear, et cetera)

Incredible course. Extremely detailed knowledge and insight into the energy system, physics behind energy, physics of renewable energy tech, energy markets, tech trends, and environmental issues. Excellent course, one of my favorites at Yale. Oristaglio is the GOAT.
Knowledge about the renewable
I learned to apply various laws of physics to solve problems related to renewable energy. I also learned many useful facts and policy.
I learned how to evaluate energy systems and the basics of a range of renewable energy technologies: hydropower, wind power, solar, bioenergy, geothermal, and wave and tidal power.
Overview of different types of renewable energy generation: hydro, wind, solar, geothermal, nuclear, energy storage, and also economics of renewables.
Course gives a very good overview of different sources of energy; be prepared for mostly qualitative info even though it's a science credit

I gained relevant insight into energy technologies, markets, and trends and built confidence working quantitatively with energy, which together helped me work directly with relevant questions like qualitatively and quantitatively comparing the characteristics, cost, and suitability of different energy sources and "predicting" future energy trends in the US / world.
Prof Oristaglio presents on a wide range of renewable energy sources while making it understandable to those with no background in the subject.
- knowledge about different renewable enegies and how they work
How to explore renewable energy on both a scientific and societal level in today's modern age.
learned about the different types of renewable energy and the science behind them
I learned the basics of renewable energy from a science and policy perspective.
A broad overview of renewable energy, energy sources and electricity generation. This relied on quantitative skills and utilising several equations.
Knowledge if renewable energy
A very solid understanding of wind, solar, hydro, bio, geothermal, and nuclear energy from physics to policy.
Learned the basic physics, logistics, and economics of main sources of renewable energy. Great overview and gets you to understand the technical stuff without getting too complicated.
I learned how to access the efficiency and output of multiple renewable energy sources such as wind and solar.
This course is a surface level topics course on various energy sources and is probably exactly what you are expecting after reading the syllabus.
Well rounded knowledge of renewable energy
learned about electricity, hydropower, wind power, solar power, nuclear energy, bioenergy, geothermal energy, and energy storage.
understanding of renewable energy systems and the math associated with them
Basics of renewable energy technology and introduction to the physics and science behind renewable energy generation.

I developed a broad understanding of how we generate and consume energy. This course helped me have a more rigorous understanding of what different renewable energy solutions can bring to the table and how we might move forward into a less carbon-intensive energy ecosystem.
Developed mathematical reasoning skills

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's difficult to tell which information is relevant, because we spend a lot of time on factual overviews of graphs or examples.
Not much work was a strength and needed office hours for help a lot

Strengths: the curriculum and the format (2 exams, 6 homework assignments, no section) were both perfect. I also appreciated the supplementary resources for those that were curious to learn even more than what was required of the course.
Weaknesses: Super long slide decks included a LOT of information, which made studying a bit harder. I enjoyed learning so much though.
A lot of the homework questions were very plug-and-chug (i.e., you don't actually need to understand the theory; you just plug numbers into an equation and get the answer).

Strengths: Extremely detailed lectures, interesting topic, extremely knowledgeable professor, assignment flexibility
Weaknesses: At 9am.
well taught
Strengths: many accommodations for students who would rather take it remotely/asynchronously; organized content; useful psets

Strengths: very informative lectures that covered each technology in the right amount of depth. I feel confident in my ability to approach detailed news articles or to work in an energy-adjacent field after taking the course. The whole course is also well organized and structured. It was fun to hear from both professors, too. Weaknesses: the midterm and final are significantly more difficult than I might have expected for the course. They're fair, and the problem sets are reasonable, but they did surprise me.

The course presented a wide variety of topics and technologies in an organized way. The slides were thorough and the problem sets generally aligned with material we covered in class. Study sessions with Professor Oristaglio were helpful. I think one way it could be improved is to have more quantitative problems.

Professor Oristaglio is clearly very very knowledgeable about the field + always gives great/thorough answers to questions. Open note exams useful in detracting the focus from memorization. Pacing speeds up considerably the last few weeks. If you're genuinely interested in the field (or want to be introduced to it), this class is great; if you're taking it as a gut, it's good in terms of workload/grading, but lectures will seem dry.

Strengths include the breadth and depth of the material, the rigor in practicing quantitative questions through several problem sets, and the availability of Prof Oristaglio and the TFs for help. One thing that could be further improved is the variety of assignments. Given the richness of the material, it would be exciting to work in groups on written assignments, presentations, or other projects where we combine the variety of knowledge and skills we learn in class into a comprehensive project. This could also take away some of the stress from the exams (and midterm exam) in particular, which - from my own experience - feel like point-assessments heavily influenced by how well you perform under pressure.
Automatic 48hr extensions on psets and flexibility with test times/dates were very helpful and accommodating of individual student needs.
- great rpofessor

Overall a very interesting class and a great way to learn about renewable energy. It was a lot more technical than I expected so be prepared for that. You will be presented with a LOT of information. This made it a little hard for me when studying for exams because it was hard to determine what is actually relevant and important. Again its great if you want to learn about renewable energy but I wasnt prepared for the amount of information wed have to know. Super interesting just dont expect it to be a true gut cause the workload isnt insignificant.

Strength: really engaging material and lectures, structured very well
Weaknesses: more transparency in feedback on psets and exams needed

strengths: super interesting material, learned a lot
weakness: didn't always get feedback on psets/exams without specifically asking for it. also the lectures often had a LOT of slides. I think shorter powerpoints could have made the lectures more engaging/easier to retain
The material is interesting and the professor is great, but the lectures can be dry at times.

Strengths: interesting content, fun mix of science and real-world content
Weaknesses: teaching style is not super engaging, and answer keys to problem sets could be more fleshed out -- I know a lot of questions have multiple correct answers, but (for example) a question that you need to solve an equation for could have an example of one possible correct equation that leads you to the answer rather than just the input values and the final answer
Awesome class!
Great content and teaching
I loved this course. The slides were extremely helpful. The problems sets were not very hard and helped to learn the material. The lectures were always extremely clear.

I thought the content was all very interesting and both Oristaglio and Ron Smith were great lecturers. I do think Smith's lecture slides could've had some more information on them, as I would typically forget some of the details that he would mention in lecture and they would show up in exams.

This course is more focused on breadth than depth. I thought it would have been more useful to learn less topics and instead delve deep into the more prominent forms of renewable energy. Instead, we learned a little about essentially every energy source. I also thought some of the lectures were quite boring due to being full of redundant or erroneous. Additionally, I found the exams to be unnecessarily long and stressful compared to the rest of the class.

This course is beautifully organized and very well explained. Professor Oristaglio is very receptive to questions and will often go out of his way to send thoughtful and detailed email responses. Some of the subjects are more fascinating than others, and the guest lectures do not add much - I wish that Professor Oristaglio had taught the course entirely. Also, although it was out of anyone's control, about half of the lectures were through Zoom, during which I learned markedly less.
Zoom was bad

Strengths: learned some things about energy that are somewhat interesting and helpful for life. I will be able to read my monthly electricity bill more critically going forward. 

Weaknesses: this class was not engaging at all. The lectures were boring. Often, the PSET questions were incongruous with the material covered in the lectures. TAs weren't always very helpful in office hours. I counted down the days til this class would end. Nothing against Prof. Oristaglio, he's great and just doing his job. I just didn't find the course material interesting, fun, engaging, or insightful at all. Grading was also too heavy on exams.
Very comprehensive, could be a bit uninteresting at times

Strengths: Professor was very flexible with extensions on psets and exams were open note which made the tests more manageable given the material covered. There were plenty of office hours and TAs were very happy to answer questions/clarify material from class. 
Weaknesses: Lectures could be a little dry at times and the first few weeks of the class were very repetitive from EPS 274.

Strengths: excellent broad-based introduction to full spectrum of renewable energy solutions, helpful and informative problem sets, practical and engaging lecture slides
Weaknesses: midterm and final were not exceptionally well-designed (too many questions, too little time)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend the course if a student has a particular interest in energy systems and the minutia of energy distribution.
Yes! I would recommend this course to anyone interested in environmental sciences. Renewable energy is an important topic and will continue to be in the future.
I would. Its a fun class

I would highly recommend this course to another student. Especially in the age of climate change and the inevitable continuation of the transition to renewable energy, this is an important class to take for anyone planning to continue living on Earth and being a responsible Earthling for the near future. It's also a rather easy class that requires no prerequisites.
Yeah. It's an interesting and relatively low workload science credit.

Absolutely. If you want a great overview of renewable energy, energy physics, energy markets, and just an overview of the world's energy system, please take this course. Professor Oristaglio is extremely informative, a great teacher, helpful, and kind. This course was excellent, enjoyed every moment of it. Guest lectures were also very well taught. As an EVST major who has come away very disappointed with courses on sustainability at Yale, this EPS one is a true gem-- take it!
Yes
Its a fun science credit. Definitely take it if youre thinking about it.

I would recommend this course as an interesting (and work-intensive) science credit. I took the course because I knew it wouldn't be a gutand indeed, it is not a gut. The week-to-week work (problems sets) are very reasonable, but the midterm and final are more difficult than you'd expect, especially in the amount of time given. But, the expectations are clearly laid out for you, the lectures are interesting, Professor Oristaglio really knows what he's talking about, and the content isall major advantages to the course. If you're ready to put the work in, I would highly recommend it.
Yes, it is a lighter course that provides good background on an important topic.

Yes, definitely. This is an incredibly comprehensive class taught by an extremely knowledgable teaching team. If not already applied during the semester itself, you will walk away with significant material to learn further from and bring with you into other classes and out of school experiences.
Yes! Its interesting and the workload is very reasonable. Professor Oristaglio also has your best interests as students in mind!
- Yes!
Absolutely, even if you're not a STEM major!
yes, it's super applicable!
Yes, I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in learning the basics of renewable energy.
Yes

This was a enjoyable, slightly more relaxed course. It was a great way to get a broad overview of energy sources but I think it definitely requires a prior interest in energy and a bit of physics knowledge. I would recommend.
Absolutely! Amazing class
Yes
I have taken no other course where I learned more per unit time than this. This class is easy and excellent; I recommend it heartily.
Yes!! If you're interested in renewable energy at all, you don't need any physics background

I would only recommend it if you are taking it for your major or very interested in a broad survey or renewable energy. However I do not think this class is a "gut", or particularly interesting/fun for someone who is not already interested in the topics.

If you are interested in the material (which, if you care about the environment, you probably should be), then this makes for an interesting surface-level introduction to modern energy. It would make an excellent fifth class or STEM course for humanities students. As a STEM student, I was a bit bored at times. Also, although it was out of anyone's control, about half of the lectures were through Zoom, during which I learned markedly less. In more normal times, there might be more field trips; I was looking forward to these, but unfortunately only one materialized this semester during the last week of the class.
Good but should be a QR

NO! do not take this class unless you are passionate about renewable energy or energy studies. This is NOT a science gut. I really didn't enjoy this class please do not take it. Find your science credit elsewhere!
If you are interested in renewable energy then yes.
Yes, I learned a lot and it has a fairly low workload. Its also not too math/science based and every physics or math concept is introduced and gone over in length so it is really manageable.
Yes! Would recommend. You'll learn a lot and the problem sets are very reasonable. Just be aware that the midterm and the final are very challenging, even if you prepare well.
Yes.  Very useful skills and knowledge about world energy systems. Applicable to life
